ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained a greater depth of appreciation for jazz improvisation; I felt like I knew what to listen for in a way that made instrumental jazz more engaging than I'd previously found it. Professor Escoffery is deeply knowledgeable about jazz history and rubbed shoulders with the greats, so he has the kind of knowledge you can't find in a textbook and is a valuable resource. Ask him for recommendations and *listen to the artists he mentions!* I learned different scales to use for improvisation, the importance of rhythm, specific lessons from individual transcriptions, and the cultural history of jazz.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Man, performing was scary sometimes but it was very worth it. The work is spaced out pretty evenly, so it's not a super-crunch to complete, which is nice for a half-credit course. Professor Escoffery can confidently provide insight for a broad variety of instruments, so it's not like it's all saxophones or anything.
Weaknesses: Some of the assignments were quite tricky (but still rewarding)! Sometimes I felt the homework and expectations were a little disorganized. I didn't have this issue, but a friend misunderstood the scope of his final performance and was asked to do something day-of that he hadn't prepared for.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: This course is fascinating and one I'm glad to have taken, although it is definitely a niche interest that won't apply to everyone (even every musician). Although engagement with the material itself is very challenging if you do it right, the actual workload isn't too crazy because Professor Escoffery is nice enough to space things out so everything's doable. You will have to be proficient enough on your instrument to participate, (definitely at least enough to confidently read back sheet music in real time), otherwise you'll have a bit of a tough time. I'd definitely recommend this course to those interested.
